results.title: The Scientist and the A.I.-Assisted, Remote-Control Killing Machine
results.abstract: Israeli agents had wanted to kill Iran’s top nuclear scientist for years. Then they came up with a way to do it with no operatives present.
results.byline: By Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi

results.title: Taliban Seize Women’s Ministry Building for Use by Religious Police
results.abstract: Taliban leaders have turned the Kabul building that housed Afghanistan’s Ministry of Women’s Affairs into the offices for the religious police, an ominous portent for women’s rights.

multimedia.caption: The new Ministry of Invitation, Guidance and Promotion of Virtue and Prevention of Vice, formerly the Ministry for Women’s Affairs, in Kabul. The compound still has murals depicting women, some now with desecrated faces, on the perimeter blast walls.

results.title: A Celebrated Virtuoso on an Instrument She Wasn’t Meant to Play

results.title: Health experts voice support for opening booster access to older and at-risk Americans.

multimedia.caption: A man receiving his third dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid vaccine in Southfield, Mich., in the days after federal regulators approved offering the shots to people whose immune systems are compromised to bring their levels of protection into a more normal range. Booster shots, by contrast, are intended to counter any waning of the protections of full vaccination.

results.title: I.M.F. chief says claims she inflated China data at World Bank are ‘not true.’
results.abstract: A World Bank investigation said Kristalina Georgieva, now the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, pressured staff to improve China’s ranking in a report when she was at the World Bank.
org_facet: Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP

multimedia.caption: “I would ask staff to please check, double-check, triple-check, but never change, never manipulate what the data tells us,” Kristalina Georgieva, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, told staff on Friday.

results.title: Britain Signals Intent to Revert to the Imperial System
results.abstract: The government announced plans to allow shops to sell produce in pounds and ounces, rather than using the metric system, as part of an effort to “capitalize on new Brexit freedoms.”

multimedia.caption: The British government said it would pursue plans to allow shops and market stalls to sell fruits and vegetables labeled solely in imperial units of measurement.

results.title: India boosts its Covid vaccine drive with 25 million shots given on Modi’s birthday.
results.abstract: After early setbacks, the inoculation push in the world’s second most populous country has gained momentum. India now counts more than 793 million administered shots.

multimedia.caption: A health worker administering a Covid-19 vaccine in Hyderabad, India, on Friday.

results.title: Black Irish, Mariah Carey’s New Liquor, Can’t Be Sold in Ireland
results.abstract: A trademark dispute with an Irish company has prevented the singer’s new line of Irish cream liqueur from reaching customers in Ireland or the rest of the European Union.

multimedia.caption: The singer Mariah Carey in Los Angeles in 2019. She and other celebrities, including George Clooney, Ryan Reynolds and Kendall Jenner, have started liquor brands in recent years.

results.title: A pilot program hints at an eventual end to Australia’s hotel quarantine system.

results.title: Merkel Leaves the German Economy With Trouble Under the Hood
results.abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel steered Europe through crises, and Germany has boomed during her tenure. But she has ducked changes needed to ensure the success lasts, analysts say.
results.byline: By Jack Ewing and Melissa Eddy

multimedia.caption: During Chancellor Angela Merkel’s tenure, economists say, Germany has neglected digital infrastructure, bungled an exit from nuclear power and become dependent on exporting to China.
multimedia.copyright: Bernd von Jutrczenka/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
